awd_titl_txt: Fate, Transport and Transformation of Ammonia Emissions from Animal Feeding Operations and Their Impacts on Air-Soil Health
awd_abstract_narration:
In the United States, animal feeding operations (AFOs) emit approximately 2.5 million tons of ammonia per year, contributing 85% of the total ammonia emissions in the nation. The fate, transport, and transformation of ammonia released from AFOs are an increasing concern due to the adverse effects of ammonia on air and water quality, soil health, and ecosystem health. This project will advance the scientific understanding of ammonia fate and transport to better understand the ecological and environmental impacts of ammonia emissions from AFOs. This knowledge will be transferred to students, industries, regulators, and the public through various educational and outreach programs that will increase the public's understanding of the environmental impacts of ammonia release from AFOs, as well as to inform policy makers to better protect human and ecological health.

This project will accomplish three specific objectives: (1) Quantify ammonia and particulate ammonium ion dry deposition impacted by ammonia emissions, land usage and meteorological conditions in AFO environments; (2) Estimate the transformation of emitted ammonia to secondary inorganic fine particulate matter as impacted by ammonia emissions, distance from source, atmospheric chemical conditions, and meteorological conditions; and (3) Quantify the impacts of ammonia and ammonium ion depositions on soil chemical and biological properties, including the microbial biomass, thestoichimetry of nitrogen transformations, and pH. Ammonia emission, deposition and transformation, and air-soil properties will be simultaneously investigated through a multi-discipline, multi-media approach at a poultry facility in North Carolina. Micrometeorological and resistance methods will be used to determine nitrogen deposition rate. Response of the soil quality metrics and nitrogen cycling rates to nitrogen deposition will be examined. Based upon simultaneous measurements of acidic gases, ammonia, and secondary inorganic fine particulate matter ions, ammonia neutralization potential will be quantified to assess the potential for particulate matter formation. This work, if successful, will produce new knowledge about: (1) the impact of reduced nitrogen deposition on soil ecosystems in rural areas; (2) the formation of secondary inorganic fine particulate matter in response to AFO ammonia emissions and ambient meteorological and chemical conditions; (3) applicability of thermodynamic equilibrium model ISORROPIA-II for the simulation of secondary inorganic fine particulate matter formation in agricultural environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

 

This project, titled "Fate, Transport, and Transformation of Ammonia Emissions from Animal Feed Operations and Their Impacts on Air-Soil Health," aimed to investigate the environmental impact of ammonia (NH₃) emissions from animal feed operations (AFOs). Funded by NSF Award No. 1804720, the project spanned from August 2018 to July 2024. The research had two primary objectives: (1) to advance understanding of how ammonia emissions from AFOs affect air quality, particularly by transforming into particulate matter (PM2.5) and depositing on soil, and (2) to disseminate findings and raise awareness among students, industry professionals, regulators, and the public.

 

Intellectual Merit

This study addressed gaps in understanding the dynamics of ammonia emissions by setting up a comprehensive air-soil sampling system at a research station and collaborating with a commercial egg production farm. Findings showed that ammonia deposition and its transformation into particulate matter were influenced by environmental factors, including temperature, humidity, and wind. The data revealed seasonal variations in ammonia deposition rates and identified conditions favoring the formation of PM2.5, contributing valuable insights into the complex interactions between agricultural emissions and atmospheric chemistry.

The project developed and refined sampling methods, including custom wet scrubber systems to measure ambient ammonia concentrations and deposition rates at various heights. These innovations allowed for precise data collection in real-world farm environments. Findings highlighted how ammonia interacts with atmospheric compounds, showing low levels of secondary inorganic PM2.5 formation, except under specific cool and humid conditions where ammonium nitrate formation increased.

 

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this work extend to environmental health and education. The project underscored the environmental risks associated with AFO emissions, which are often located near rural communities. By quantifying ammonia’s effects on soil acidity and nitrogen transformations, the study demonstrated how AFO emissions could influence local ecosystems and agricultural soils, leading to potentially adverse shifts in soil pH and nutrient balance.

In addition, the project emphasized educational outreach, engaging K-12 students and supporting a diverse group of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers. The project hosted virtual outreach events and provided hands-on training in air quality monitoring, reaching both local and remote communities affected by agricultural emissions. Findings from this study were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and student theses, fostering a deeper understanding of AFO emissions in the scientific community.

 

Summary of Outcomes

The outcomes of this research include:

  1. Scientific Advancements: Developed reliable methods for measuring ammonia deposition and identified environmental conditions that exacerbate or mitigate ammonia’s transformation into particulate matter. This work enhances predictive models for ammonia transformation, with implications for air quality management and regulation.
  2. Environmental Insights: Showed that ammonia deposition from AFOs could lower soil pH, impacting microbial activity and nutrient cycles. These findings are important for managing soil health in regions with high agricultural activity.
  3. Education and Outreach: Conducted outreach to K-12 students and provided training to students across educational levels, including high school internships and research opportunities for undergraduates and graduates. These efforts helped build awareness of environmental issues related to agricultural emissions.
  4. Research Dissemination: Published findings in academic journals and presented at scientific conferences, contributing to the body of knowledge on air quality and agricultural emissions.

 

In summary, this project not only contributed to scientific understanding of ammonia's environmental impacts but also engaged the next generation of scientists and raised awareness of agricultural emissions' broader environmental implications.
